The hotel is very well located, within walking distance to Ala Moana and Wakiki. The interior is by no means magnificent but everything was perfectly lovely and adequate. The double room we had was very spacious and there was a second sink in the room against the bathroom wall, which made it so much easier for my husband and I to get ready in the morning. The only downside perhaps is if you are walking towards Wakiki, taking a right turn out the main entrance will lead you through a rather sketchy neighbourhood filled with back alley ways and strip clubs. But turning left and walking onto the main road is a good alternative, just a bit more of a walk.

Recently my family and I stayed at the Pagoda Hotel. We were very happy with the Hotel and Staff during our stay, The deskclerk changed one of the rooms so we could be on the same floor and were helpful with anything we asked. If we return to Honolulu, we plan on booking at the Pagoda again.

I had a job interview and chose to stay at the Pagoda because of the price. At first, I was disappointed that I was not in the heart of Waikiki where I usually stay, but after walking around the area I was surprised with the location. I walked to my nearby 24 hour fitness club, the Ala Moana Mall as well as numerous "hole in the wall" restaurants which featured inexpensive local and asian cusines. If you want to walk into Waikiki, it really is not that far, or just jump on the bus on nearby Kapiolani and a few minutes later you are in Waikiki for less than $2.00. If you are looking for a clean, inexpensive place to stay, check it out. I was a flight attendant for 30 years and know what I am talking about.

I've stayed here a couple of times while on Oahu for an Ultimate Frisbee tournament. The rooms are nothing special, but they get the job done, and the staff has always been friendly. It's a couple blocks walk from the mall, and one of the cheaper options I've seen in Honolulu. Would stay here again with my sports team, but probably not on a nicer vacation

Enjoyed my 5 night stay at the Pagoda because of its location (out of the Waikiki area), friendly staff, and proximity to excellent shopping (Ala Moana shopping center, Walmart, Sam's Club, Don Quiote super market, and Ward Center, Rooms are spacious, though dated, are clean, and the housekeeping service was excellent. The room/car special rate was good and includes ample hotel parking which saved $10 per day in added expense. The only drawback was the lack of WiFi service though a nearby Internet cafe provided the internet service at a reasonable cost of $4 per hour.
If you want a clean affordable place to sleep this is it. It's not fancy, but the location is convenient and why spend a lot of your vacation money on a room you will only be in long enough to sleep.

review_body: The Pagoda is great for people travelling on a budget. It is conveniently located OUTSIDE WAIKIKI and has a lot of different options. We stayed on the Terrace side so we had cooking facilities, large closets and lots of room. Bill at the front desk and the housekeeping staff (especially Esther and Cora) were great. I am glad the place is being refurbished since it had gone down hill in recent years. New paint, new dishes and cooking utensils and the removal of the horrible carpet from the hallways has made a big change. The staff seems really happy under the new management. So I look forward to even more change when I return in the future.

This place is centrally located and made our stay very convenient. We were able to do some shopping as it was really close to a Ross store and Walmart, the Ala Moana mall and restaurants. The restaurant at the hotel made it even more convenient for my son and I since we didn't feel like walking outside the hotel after dark to have dinner. The hotel was obviously dated but it was clean and the bed was comfortable. Friendly and helpful staff.

Although the hotel is outdated. They have done some up-grades, new beds, entrance flooring, newly painted rooms, clean carpets, good air-con & fridge, also some rooms have new beds that are so comfortable. Bill, Souki, Marlon & the housekeepers gave us a warm welcome & excellent service. Forgot to mention there is a microwave as well. The price is good, this is hotel side. The TERRACE has a full kitchen.

Always stay at The Pagoda Hotel whenever I go to Honolulu for business or pleasure. Staff is the best and the location is close for shopping or eating. Facilities may need some upgrading, but the housekeeping staff keeps everything clean and spotless. Front desk & telephone operators are super.
The hotel is very clean, all staff were very professional, the hotel is very nice, it exceeded my expectations.

Stayed over night, from front desk to maid service, staff was really friendly. Came from Molokai to shop and the location is perfect. Facilities and accommodations was great. Recommend to all family and friends

I have stayed here a few times over the years. It isn't anything fancy and the rooms are fairly old. The best part about it is it's location. It is within walking distance to Ala Moana mall and everything inbetween and it's only a 10 minute walk to the beach.

We stayed here for one night while in transit from ATL to Australia. The hotel was chosen for the nearby location of the Ala Moana mall, the price, and the seemingly better reviews than the airport hotels. The service we had at check in was what I would expect from any hotel and I certainly didn't feel like the staff went out of their way to help us, as some of the reviews might lead you to believe. The hotel is in desperate need of renovation and felt dirty and rundown. Based on the pictures I had seen online I was expecting something nicer. We had requested a non-smoking room and although the room was labeled as such, it still smelled of cigarette smoke and the quilt on the bed had a cigarette burn in it. We had no problems with bugs the night we were there. The room is not soundproof and we could hear lots of street noise lasting until after midnight. The bed was more comfortable than I was expecting after first seeing the room and despite the noise we managed a good nights sleep. The hotel is a 5-10 min walk to the Ala Moana mall where there is an abundance of food options. The convenient location does not make up for the condition of the hotel and if we were to come back through HNL for only one night again we would probably look somewhere else if this hotel has not been fully renovated.
I really enjoy staying at the Pagoda. The location is great, the staff are friendly and always willing to help! I certainly recommend it!
The service was great and rooms were nice.We hope to stay again soon! Mahalo

My friends and I stayed at the Pagoda Hotel for a get together. When we checked in, the guy Marlon was SUPER KOOL..!!! The Pagoda has an old reputation for being a simple but comfortable place in a great location. The location is still great, but the new owners are not maintaining the property. review_body: Arrived at the hotel with no waiting line and received excellent customer service by Suki. Very friendly and comfortable experience as always by the entire hotel staff. The location is great and the prices are reasonable. Mahalo nui loa.

The Pagoda Hotel in Honolulu has had its day. I'm sure that there was a time when it was quite a substantial property, well liked and respected. I spoke to locals who said that its restaurant was once well-regarded and people came from far around to eat there. Not anymore. I recently stayed at the Pagoda as part of a conference delegation. Locals who I spoke to were shocked that an international delegation would be put there. It's old, tired and in a fairly dodgy area, with seedy s-x shops dotting the neighbourhood and the sort of people hanging around the hotel foyer that you would not want to mix with. It's also a very noisy neighbourhood and sound proofing has not been undertaken in the hotel. The hotel is clean and the staff are alright, but the place is tired and ugly. A full renovation is required, but this may not be possible. A bulldozer might be the only solution. Note, the hotel is also a considerable walk from Waikiki so don't believe promotional material which suggests it is just around the corner. It is quite poorly located. Finally, this hotel is NOT cheap. You could pay an extra $20 US a night and get a much nicer hotel in central Waikiki.

I thought Marlon did a very good job in helping me extend my stay by one more night. He was very helpful and kind in his manner and by the way he interacted with the other customers as well. Well done! Riza

This the hotel of choice when the family travels to Honolulu from the outer islands. It has been over 10 years since I've been to Pagoda Hotel but still remains is the admirable, friendly staff and wonderful restaurant Koi fish ponds. This hotel has made some great and impressive improvements pertaining to room renovations. I felt very comfortable given the very spacious two-bedroom suite that has a larger layout than most hotels suites. The perfect sized bathroom was newly renovated with brand new fixtures and super CLEAN, which is so important for me. Due to my short stay, the charming full kitchen wasn't utilized much but i really appreciated the full-sized refrigerator to keep beverages chilled. Rooms were large and beds are comfortable. I managed to get breakfast and tasted for the first time Kalua pig hash which was appetizing with fried rice and eggs; "ONO"-the food has always been excellent at Pagoda. Reluctant to say that I've always known this property to be in a bad environment area. Too many random people roaming around the property and parking lots. Got there late in the evening but Marlon at the front desk was ever so obliging trying to find me a room. Because of the Hoolauea going on that weekend many hotels, even not directly in Waikiki were filled. Marlon kindly offered me a 1 bedroom suite across the street from the main lobby hotel. A little reluctant but because of his curious manner and assistance we took the room. Second floor with not too much noises if you keep the jealousies close tightly it wasn't too bad at all. Another pleasant thought was Pagoda's floating restaurant across the street has a nice Sunday buffet brunch, which of course we had to enjoy in. Feed the beautiful plump koi's and had a hardy meal looking amongst a garden scene and even ducks in the ponds. Our room was actually fairly nice and it was clean, ac was cool. A little musty smell when we got there, but eventually got more pleasant after awhile.

After being built almost 50 years ago the Pagoda Hotel immediately earned a well-deserved reputation for being the quintessential Hawaiian hotel serving the needs of local travelers. Over the many years the Pagoda has always been my home away from home whenever visiting Honolulu, my last stay being only two weeks ago. A thirteen-floor tower offers rooms that are large enough to easily accommodate the needs of a traveling couple. Across the street from the tower is a complex of apartment type rooms complete with kitchens and separate bedrooms suitable for traveling families. Additionally, the hotel’s onsite restaurant offers an eclectic selection of food dishes designed to satisfy the palate of any traveler. Alas however with the passing of time coupled with ever changing travelers’ demographics, the Pagoda has sadly long since lost its initial luster. Five decades of wear and tear have taken their toil and now only a major overhaul can restore this venerable establishment to current standards found in more modern-day hotels, of which there are many to choose from in Honolulu. During my most recent visit to the Pagoda, one of the two balky elevators refused to function properly leaving in its wake long standing lines of disgruntled visitors. My room, while certainly clean enough, was as usual compromised with an undersized and noisy air window conditioner. To make matters worse, the one time enormously popular Pagoda Floating Restaurant had radically reduced its hours making dining options very problematic at best. Not even the still wonderful garden ambiance complete with its multi-hued koi fishpond could compensate for me these encountered shortcomings. As it currently stands, if you’re visiting Hawaii seeking a tropical reprise the Pagoda is probably not the hotel for you. One would be well advised to seek something closer to the center of Waikiki, which is another two miles away. Even if you can’t afford an ocean front room and must walk a few blocks to Hawaii’s premier beach, there’s something to be said for the experience of a strolling leisurely past the numerous exotic visitors’ attractions en route to a white sandy beach. However, if you’re simply looking for no frill accommodations for a couple of days and don’t mind mixing in with a sometimes raucous crowd, the Pagoda is as good (or worse) as any other you might find in Honolulu. Just be forewarned to remember grandma’s advice…. you get what you pay for!

first off, the noise level is ridiculous. at 1 o'clock, you do not need anyone yelling and screaming while your trying to sleep. second, the rooms are old and ugly. it looks more like a motel then a hotel. and lastly, the smell of smoke is embedded in the hallways, which causes you to smell smoke while in your room. even the bedding smells of smoke. when asked if we could change because the smell was just too much.. we got no help. overall, it was a very bad experience!

We are a medical mission group that stayed there in July. New management but reservations went thru fairly smoothly. We have stayed there for many years because of the location. In years past, we have enjoyed your breakfast buffett even though we had to pay for it. This year it was not available, which was a bummer. Staff was nice but did not apologize for not having our rooms ready. We stay in the hotel, not the terrace. We tried the terrace one year and it was awful. Will probably stay again next year because of location. Looking forward for new management to add some things! It would be nice.

Stayed here recently and only have good things to say. The prices are good and very affordable. The rooms are kept clean and the staff are very helpful and friendly! The area is a good one as they are close to shopping center, grocery store, wal mart and restaurants. Highly recommend to anyone!

Recently stayed the night at the Pagoda Hotel in Honolulu. A clean, affordable room and every staff member i came into contact with was friendly and professsional. Very Special thanks to Suki, Kovy, and Albert for making my short visit so great!!!!

Stayed here for the first time and found the location to be great. There are a lot of conveniences close by. For shopping there's Ala Moana Shopping Center, Sam's Club, Walmart, Walgreens and Don Quiote, a grocery/department store (fun place to explore), all within a few blocks. There's a restaurant in the hotel, a 24 restaurant next door, a Starbucks nearby and tons of little places to eat within walking distance. I did not deal with the staff much, but the little I did they were friendly and very helpful. It's not a Marriott, but, if you're looking for a really reasonable, comfortable and centrally located place to base out of this place is great. The beach is not close by, but, definitely within walking distance.

First, the good - I love that it's in an excellent location....close to Ala Moana S/C, Sam's Club and Walmart, restaurants, etc. As a former Oahu resident, I stayed here many times. I knew what to expect. I love the lobby and the lay-back feel you get when you enter. Free daily (except Sunday) newspapers are a good thing. :) Good to also have computer access in the lobby, and I have no objection to paying for using it. Would be a big plus if guests can access and print out their boarding passes for free, though. The room was acceptable (outside noises - early, like 5AM...delivery trucks, garbage trucks, etc.). Cannot sleep in, that's for sure! I hope someone can confirm this for me: I stayed there for 4 nights. On my second day there, I was out all day....came back to my room approx. 3pm to find the beds were not made and there were no new towels, etc. When I called Housekeeping, I was told they clean rooms only once a week. Is this for real?? For the duration of my stay, I had to ask the maid daily for clean towels, soap, tissue, whatever was needed. I always leave a tip for maid service, but because they didn't tend to my room, I got to keep the $$. That's a good thing! :)P.S. ~~ There's a local restaurant within walking distance....Likelike Drive-Inn. Way over-priced. Please go with caution. I went there once with 2 other people for breakfast - nothing fancy - omelets, pancakes....spent close to $50! Holy crap. Half a papaya will set you back $4. That's ridiculous.....

This hotel is away from the coast. it is dingy and old. no parking. you have to park above the Ross department store across the street. This not the property you want to stay in. This hotel is in need of a remodel.....desperatly!

I've stayed at the Pagoda many times because I like the quaintness of the hotel, nice breeze in the lobby, friendliness of the staff, and most of all, the location. This last time was particularly poor, though, as we had to change our room three different times and we never did get a good, quiet room. To the new hotel management: I don't mind the old furniture and old pictures on the wall or the sink/bathroom decour. If you have limited funds to invest please, please consider the following suggestions from someone who has stayed there many times: 1) get new drapes that are thick enough to block the incoming light from outside; 2) get new, soft velour blankets for all the beds; 3) get sheets that are long enough to span the entire length of the bed; 4) place a microwave & fridge in every room. If you want to compare favorably with other hotels in the area, then you should consider offering free Internet service to guests (including password for lobby computer), some token breakfast items, and free newspapers (USA Today & Honolulu Advertisor). And, you shouldn't be charging extra for coffee - that's ridiculous, considering the price of the room! I suffer from migraines and really need to sleep in a dark place. I'd pay extra for a room with darkening curtains.

Too top it all off broken aircon I swore never again would I stay at the Pagoda - dirty sheets we were bitten by bed bugs all night and woke up with bite/welts all over.nicknamed by my kids"Pa-grow-ta"

It is not only outdated but run down to the the fibers of the carpet. This should be a motel instead of a hotel. Not only were the rooms in horrible conditions, it was so loud and noisy. I wish I had brought a sleeping bag and a tent. I would have had better accomodations and maybe even get to sleep.

I stayed in the Pagoda for 2 nights. A Sat and Sunday night and I was in the main tower. I had a King room on the 11th floor and I was surprised ,based on the previous reviews, how nice it was. I had no problems with noise, dirty carpets or anything else. It was nice clean and the window air conditioner worked fine.I had my reservations about staying here,but decided to give it a try and I am glad I did. I will definitely stay here again. It is perfect spot for me to walk everywhere and goto Sams/Walmart ...Alot of restaurants around too...

Stayed for a week and was in the terrace -- a smaller building across the street from the main hotel. I looked in need of repair but the layout had potential in a Melrose Place sort of way. There was a small pool area in the center of the 5-story building. We chose this place because the rooms had 4 separate beds + kitchenette and that's exactly what we needed.The room we had was generally clean but when furniture and appliances get older they just get to that point where they look dirty no matter how much you clean them. The rooms were big though. The staff was also very nice but the five minutes you spend interacting with staff really don't make up for the biggest issue - NOISE.It seems as though many of the people -- families in particular -- who were staying there that week didn't understand that the HALLWAYS ARE NOT PART OF THEIR ROOMS. We heard kids and adults talking, yelling, running around the halls at all times of day and night. 12 noon, maybe it's okay. But at 3 or 4 AM? COME ON. And playing guitar and singing??? There's only so much asking you can do for people to be quiet without starting to feel that it's futile. It also seemed like there was a kids' pool party going on every day. I really don't know where all the kids came from.We saw the door for the Security Office downstairs but never happened to see a security guard. I think this noise problem could be solved if they actually had someone who just strolled about the halls every hour or so and told people to go into their rooms and close their doors if they were being noisy, but also after 10 at night -- no matter what. Seriously people, go in your room and shut your door! Another noise-related issues was the doors -- both the knocking and the constant slamming. It seemed like everyone but us on our floor knew each other. Kocking -- slamming -- knocking - slamming. Again at all times of the day. Our room was also unfortunately near the stairwell whose door squeaked and slammed all the time. If they would get someone to WD-40 the doors and maybe adjust the door closers so they didn't slam shut then maybe they'd be able to fix this issue as well.Needless to say we bought earplugs as soon as we could but it should not be that way.Oh, and the water hammer in that building was by far the worst I've ever heard. Every time someone would use a sink in our unit or above or below or next door you could hear the pipes hammering at you when the water got shut off. I swear to God we could have all gotten drunk playing a drinking game based on the water hammer noises.Lastly, the elevators, particularly the one nearest our room smelled AWFUL. It was like the combination of a bunch of strong chemicals and you seriously lost your appetite if you didn't hold your breath. I really don't understand putting carpeting in there. Why not a tile or pergo floor or something that could be easily cleaned that would NOT soak up whatever stench happens upon it?Anyhow, I heard that the hotel was recently under new ownership so I hope the new owners do something about this -- in which case my review would be null and void. But as of Jan 2011 the above seems to be the case.

My husband,friends and I stayed here on New Years Eve since we were going to be partying in town. We figured we'll stay somewhere cheap since we were only going to be using it to sleep. Big Mistake! Even just using it to sleep was bad. I stayed in the Pagoda Tower before which was decent.This time, however, we were set up at the Pagoda Terrace. This was more like an apartment complex! The rooms were old,the carpet was dirty,one of the little sample shampoo bottles were half full like it was used, and talk about the noise outside! At 4 in the morning there was domestics going on outside and we could hear people walking back and forth in front of our room. Also, it seemed like there were a lot of micronesian families who stay/live there for some reason.I would never stay there again, or at least never in the Pagoda Terrace!

I arrived from the HNL airport, $30 fare at 5am. Check in was quick and easy as i had a reservation. I stayed on the 3rd floor. The room was clean but the carpets are worn out. The size of the room was surprsingly large. I thought it was strabge to have a sink beside the bed though. The only drawback is that the A/C is a window unit and kind of noisy. The curtains are kind of thin and let alot of street light into the room.The best part is location. Lots of places to eat, and a few bars in the area. Walmart is juts down the street and is an easy walk.Overall its cheap, safe and a great location but not a glamerous place.

A group of 25 people stayed there for two weeks. The Hotel is split in two - there is the Pagoda Tower and Pagoda Terraces. We stayed in the Pagoda Terraces which bear no resemblance whatsoever to the photos that are on the website. The outside was dirty and run down and there are carpeted veranda's leading to the rooms and the carpets were filthy. The first night we arrived there was a fight next door to one of our rooms which scared the people so much so they wanted to leave immediately and we had only just arrived. In another room we found cockroaches and ants, in another there were dirty clothes and underwear under the bed. In some rooms the air con wasn't working and in every single room there were utensils, crockery and pots and pans missing. The one thing in its favour is that it is close to the centre of the city. It is a tired and run down and the staff are not friendly except for Richard the Security guy.

I was there for a conference and leisure. The good things about the Pagoda were the Koi fish, they were beautiful & the location to shops, it was a bit far away from the beach (10-15min walk). This accommodation was not organised by us, but by Navigator Tours NZ (who I would not recommend). However the cleanliness of the place was very poor (our fridge/freezer was mouldy), the room stunk and we did not want to take our shoes off to walk on the carpet. The pool is locked at 7pm all though it is still very hot. Not many of the staff smile when you approach them either...haha.... that was stink.I would say look around if you are not from the USA, there are better places to stay for the same value as people who booked out after 1 nights stay (booked in for 10 days) found.

This time was the same as all the other times, except I finally noticed the smell. It's the smell of the air of the neighborhood. You can especially smell it by Don Q/Daisei. For the room I was in this August, it was clean and a good place to spend the night (I was only there for 1 night this time). It's a good location, but unfortunately the location it's in is kind of smelly. If you're just looking for a room to sleep in, then Pagoda's pretty much for you.

We picked the Pagoda because of the location to the airport and close enough for us to walk to Ala Moana for dinner that night. My first clue that this place was going to be an absolute dump was when the receptionist directed us to a building accross the street. This place didn't even look like a hotel, it look like an apartment complex where people lived. The folks next to us must have had 20 people crammed into the room. All 3 rooms that we rented were equally bad. We had to crank up the A/C just to mask the awful smell. The carpet looked like it had not been changed in 50 years. The beds, I think they picked up from a city dump. They were so bad that sleeping on the floor probably would have been better. The sheets were so thin that if you pulled on them it probably would have ripped. The bathroom had broken tile, and the showers were probably original from the 1940's. I have traveled all over the US and the World, and this place I have to say is probably the worst place I have ever stayed at. Save yourself from grief and don't bother staying at the Pagoda. I can't say enough bad things about this place. One last thing, you probably don't need a wake up call as the bums/drunks are so loud that they'll surely keep you up.

This is a decent hotel for a decent price right in the middle of Honolulu. A lot of Hawai'ian residents from neighbor islands stay there. It has a tremendous local flavor. Parking is free in the Ross for Less lot across the street--get a validated ticket from the hotel. It's within walking distance of Sam's, Walmart, Ala Moana Shopping Center, and other wonderful local spots. I ate breakfast daily at the Like Like Diner and loved it for all its local color. You can't beat the price, either. It's not the Ritz but it works for me.

Stayed here for one night and couldn't wait to check out and leave. The walls are paper thin, we could hear the neighbors converstion clear as day. Curtins were slashed, carpet had many stains and very dusty, I didn't want to walk on the carpet bare foot. Tiles in the bathtub was chipped and bath towels are paper thin and doors don't lock properly. Hotel is in dire need of an upgrade. I would rather sleep in my rental car than stay here again.

When we checked in the front desk agent (haole girl) not friendly, basically "give me your money, here is your keys! Bye". pagoda hotel is situated in neither the main tourist area nor business area, yet convient to both. easy access via hwy or nimitz from the airport. within minutes walking of the ala moana mall/wal-mart/sam's club/starbucks. or, for a nice meal, onsite pagoda restaurant is very nice. hotel has friendly staff, on site mini-mart and pool. off street parking available at nominal fee. for those who don't mind walking, you can walk to waikiki beach or the main shopping (tourist) streets. rooms have fridge & coffee pot. i visit hawaii generally every 6 to 8 weeks & always stay at pagoda.

My husband, 6-year-old niece, and I had reservations here for a room with 1 queen and 1 twin. When we arrived after our 20-hour voyage to Hawaii, I signed in, very tired, and went to the room, where they had mistakenly given us just 1 queen-size bed. My growing niece kicks a lot and needs her own bed. When I went to the front desk, the receptionist (a male) listened and rudely, without saying anything, snapped out the sheet where I had signed for the room and pointed to my signature. He was implying that since I had not bothered to check what I had signed, he wasn't obligated to correct our room. Offended, I explained the situation to him and showed him a printout of our reservation. He glared at me and grumbled. Then I asked to speak to his manager. A girl came and corrected our room, upgrading us to one with 4 beds for the same price as our reservation. When we entered our room, the carpet was nearly paper thin and filthy. For all 7 days, the hallway smelt like marijuana. My sister, who lives on the island, told me that the Hawaii State Immigration puts immigrants up at this hotel during their processing and that head lice was rumored in this hotel. Our room had a full kitchen, and judging our neighbors, I think some of them were living there. At the main complex, the pond with the carp that used to be nice and clear in the 1980s had so much green algae that you could barely see the fish. I was surprised the fish were able to move in it! The hotel probably wouldn't know if the fish were dying because they can't see the fish anyway unless they swim to the surface for air. Once a nice hotel, the Pagoda has now gone to the dogs. The male receptionist shocked me and offended me. I wouldn't stay here again for anything.

It's an old dump...there...I said it. The place is filthy and run down. My feet got dirty from the carpet, the room and hallways smelled old, there was blood on my sheets...no hot water. Worst of all....nobody cared when I complained! The service was so bad...with an attitude of..."we've got your money...now what are you going to do".Never...ever....stay here!!!

I was at the Pagoda Hotel last month for a week - granted it was not for any kind of pleasure trip - I live on Kaua'i and my mother was flown to Straub Clinic (she died the following week) - so I was there on my own and had never stayed at any Honolulu property by myself before. It was super clean, the staff was very friendly and when they knew I was there on my own they always seemed to be making sure I was okay. I felt very safe there at all times.The room was absolutely great - not fancy, just clean, basic, even a sliver of an ocean view (I was on the 9th floor) - I was very happy with it and with the service. They even put a newspaper in front of my door every morning. Bedding immaculate and I appreciated the coffee maker big time!I chose it primarily because I could walk to Straub Clinic from there, but it was also in an area that I felt very safe in - I could eat right around the corner at one of my favorites - Likelike Drive In and feel right at home. Also Ala Moana Center was closeby and easy to walk to if you wanted.It was not a fun trip - but the friendliness and overall great local atmosphere at this hotel made a difficult time much easier. I was also appreciative of the fully stocked Sundries Store downstairs.I think this property is a great one - especially for kama'aina who aren't looking for a Waikiki Beach experience, but a good, clean hotel in a central location.

We needed somewhere to rest for a 20 hour lay over & ended up here because it is walking distance to Ala Moana shopping center. We booked a double room & got 2 very uncomfortable single beds. After a 3 am check-in I thought I'd be able to sleep any way, but the bed was too uncomfortable to stay in it past 7 am. We paid around $100 & weren't happy for what we received, but I guess Honolulu is just plain expensive, & you need to spend a minimum of $150 to be comfortable. We'll know next time!

No need to say again all the terrible things said by others. It is dingy, in need of some remodeling, and just feels dirty. I had two showers without hot water. The window air conditioner could not cool the room, and it just felt stuffy. The towels are thin and rough, the sheets feel old. The garbage truck woke me each morning, but that is not their fault. This hotel has the basics, but nothing more. There is a mildew-y smell throughout the hotel that could give some people with allergies a problem. Be fore-warned: this hotel is not near the water, it is near Wal-Mart, Sam's, Ala Moana Shopping Center, and Ross Dress for Less. If you are looking for beach view, easy walk to the beach, or the feel of winds flowing through your room this is not the place. The staff seemed courteous and efficient.

At first glance it seemed like an old but OK place to spend a couple of nights....location is great, Sam's & Wal-Mart at walking distance, until you make it inside the rooms to discover that they are dirty and poorly maintianed, bath tub was filthy and when taking a shower the water went from extremely cold to extremely hot all on its own.The worst happen the next morning when my daughters and I woke up full of bedbug bites all over our bodies. Bailed out of there like a smoking bandit!!

We did not stay or visit anyone staying at the Hotel Tower of this two buidling outfit. This review is based on our seven day stay in a two bedroom suite at their Terrace building.Our first suite on the second floor had a dead fridge and needed to be gutted and redone. Our second suite on the fourth floor wasn't much better but the fridge and A/C's worked. The flooring, carpeting, restroom, kitchenette and in-window A/C's had outlived their usable lifespans years ago. The suite was clean though. Their cleaning staff should be commended for the effort that they put in trying to make the rooms look presentable which is not easy considering the sad state of repair and upkeep that they are in. Unfortunately, there is there isn't enough lipstick in the island to make this pig look like anything but a pig. There were no bugs seen but the pigeons nesting outside our windows acting as our sunrise alarm every morning got to be a little annoying.Overall, our stay was not terrible since we were using the suite just as a place to sleep and shower.

The Pagoda Hotel doesn't show up in many guidebooks, but holds a nostalgic place in my mind because that's where my family stayed on our first trip to Hawaii, 35 years ago. This review, however, is based on a stay this year!The hotel is in Honolulu proper, a few blocks from the Ala Moana Shopping Center, but is not next to Waikiki -- one reason it seldom gets mentioned. For frequent visitors who don't need the full resort experience, though, it is more than adequate. The price, at least when booked through their web site, is excellent, and parking is plentiful (there's a charge, but a lot less than most other properties).There are two separate buildings -- the tower and the terrace. The terrace is actually across the street from the tower, which is connected to the check-in desk and the restaurant. I stayed in the tower, and found my room to be more than adequately large. I was impressed that there was a sink separate from the bathroom, which also had a sink, facilitating matters for those sharing the room with others. There were also a refrigerator, a microwave oven, and a safe -- all handy to have! Incidentally, each building has its own swimming pool, so no inconvenience there.Desk staff were friendly and efficient, as was the woman tending the shopette. I can't say that I had any interaction with other hotel staff.Shopette prices, by the way, are more than reasonable, quite a difference from even the mid-range properties in the US.The restaurant is renowned for its koi pond, for good reason. The pond surrounds the entire restaurant, and there are lots of tables at the windows and on a small lanai that allow views of the fish (or you can see them from the walkways outside). Feeding is scheduled for several times daily.For the daily breakfast buffet, the food is good but not spectacular. For the price, though, I'm not complaining. Sunday brunch (served after breakfast) and nightly dinner are also buffets, but I didn't partake this time. Hint: be sure to have reservations for dinner; I didn't eat dinner there because I didn't have a reservation and didn't want to wait 2 hours!I had a couple minor quibbles with the room. First, the plumbing in the tub could have been secured a bit better. I tried to adjust the shower head, and the cap hiding the hole in the wall slid all the way down the pipe.More important -- to me, anyway -- was the inefficiency of the air conditioning in the room. I realize I'm visiting the tropics, but when A/C is provided I do like it to work. It was provided by a window-mounted unit, which had a huge gap between the unit and the wall beneath it. Fortunately, I didn't notice any critters coming in, but there was a lot of gunk in there that should have been cleaned out. Also, the unit wasn't large enough to do its job. The temperature in the room was actually quite comfortable, but I was trying to lower the humidity a bit. I ran the air conditioning on high cool, full cold temperature for 48 hours and it was finally starting to make a difference when I checked out.The only other advice I would provide is that while the hotel's address is on Rycroft Street, and the main entrance (a breezeway, not a door) is indeed there, the parking is behind the property on Kanunu Street. There is a small parking lot, while validated parking is available in the Ross Dress for Less garage across the street (levels 4 through 7 for hotel guests). Since two school buses were taking up the entire space in front of the hotel entrance, I ended up feeding a meter and walking back to the hotel because there was no advance indication of where to park.To sum up, I recommend this hotel for those who don't need a resort experience, don't need to be right on the beach, and don't need a lot of fancy amenities. If you just want to be pampered, you're better off elsewhere, but for those of us with more pedestrian tastes the Pagoda is quite suitable.

This is the thrid time I have stayed at this property over the past few years and it is a functional place to hang your hat in Honolulu. It is not five-star and doesn't claim to be. It is, however, a clean, basic hotel with a pretty good location.You are near the massive Ala Moana Mall for mall wants and Wakmart's is walking distance if that is important.The cab ride to Waikiki is about $9 each way and you can walk it in about 45 minutes if you choose.I didn't make use of the pool or the restaurants as there are alot of places in the neighborhood to eat.It was interesting to shower here, though. If you are over 6 feet tall, you may have to bend a bit to fit under the shower head.I got a business rate for $90/night. If you can get a deal and just care about a place to sleep and shower, it is a decent option.

While this hotel is older and could use some updates it is also clean and comfortable. It was centrally located and within walking distance of many great restarants and you could be at the beach in 10 minutes. If what you wanted to see was not within walking distance you could hop a trolley for a small fee and get just about anywhere. The staff were friendly and accommodating. Noise, smell, service can only be tolerated by people of Hawai'i or those who just need a crash pad. Rooms, service, setting are just above a motel6 (and that is only because you're in Hawai'i and the location is great). Would not recommend the hotel to vacationers who have something better in mind. Sad because I think this hotel can be so much more. Great stay at Xmas...mall is walking distance.

i stayed at this hotel awhile back and its not that bad. there are more pros than there are cons. their entire staff were very accommodating. all except for the one security guard. the pool was pretty big and had enough lounge chairs. there was a sundry shop on site so you could pick up the necessities. and there was a (daiei?) store that sold groceries right across the street. location wasnt that bad depending on how you look at it. theres a bus stop around the corner, though it's quite a hike after a long day of sightseeing/shopping. we did get a car but parking was pretty scarce. youd have to park about a hundred yards away to find an available stall. we only drove when we werent shopping. ala moana shopping center is the best mall which is right down the street. however, at night, there isnt really that much to do without losing your parking stall and heading into waikiki. pagoda is on the other side of waikiki where you dont get that noisy feeling. some of which is great unless you want to be immersed in the action. housekeeping was awesome. they came in on a daily basis. there was a restaurant on property which was great. they have a koi pond that blows your mind. the pagoda is really one of those places to have a clean room without breaking the budget. great service, adequate location, great price.

My parents grew up in Hawaii and like to have a place to stay that doesn't involve Relatives and so they stay at the Pagoda. Location and price is their foremost concern which are the true advantages to this hotel. Location is good for those who like being conveniently located in the midst of Honolulu but without the excess press of people (and cars) that characterize Waikiki. The hotel is very near a Walmart and Ala Moana Mall and, if you didn't know, has its own well known restaurant downstairs. A decent diner is also located in the retail complex next door and a sprinkling of other restaurants abound in the area (mostly ethnic). Price is reasonable for a hotel in Honolulu. What you should keep in mind is that Hawaii's largest industry is tourism so a lot of hotels have been around for a long time. This makes the average hotel in Hawaii fairly aged, unless or despite renovations. So you're not being cheated for what you get; that's just how it is in Honolulu.I've stayed with my parents a number of times at the Pagoda. Each time, we get a moderate room in the hotel tower. Usually we get one fairly high up, because you do have some street noise (not like Waikiki but sometimes loud cars or teens, etc). Parking for the hotel tower (the one without the kitchenettes) is usually in the small restaurant/hotel parking lot below or across the street in the upper levels of the parking garage. You do pay for the parking; the front desk gives you a pass that you put on your dash. Rooms are nothing special, definitely dated but clean. We've stayed there at least 8 times over as many years and nothing we've seen has been revolting. The hotel tower usually have a small fridge, microwave, and coffee maker which is what my parents really appreciate. The pool at the hotel tower (I understand there's another one for the terrace) never seems to have a lot of people in it (usually one family at a time) but was definitely small. If you're unlucky I'd say 6 to 8 guests would stuff it to the gills. We've never had a problem with the hotel staff, but we don't usually ask for much besides a lot of extra towels, which the cleaning ladies usually give us immediately.This isn't a place to get excited about, especially if you're making a special trip to Hawaii for that much anticipated family vacation. It isn't in the bustle of excitement that makes Waikiki and isn't very near any beaches. What it is is a decent affordable hotel to rest and sleep before going back out into the tropical sunshine.

We stayed here for 2 nights during the Pro Bowl. Staff was friendly, the rooms were clean. It is old, no doubt, and the 2 star rating is probably accurate.But this is Hawaii, after all. How long are you going to be inside your hotel?The restaurant is quite good, the gardens are attractive. It is within walking distance of several small restaurants of various ethnic flavors, and a longer walk from Ala Moana Shopping Center. I'd stay here again.

We stayed at the Pagoda in Honolulu June 2006, in a family room (2 bedrooms with kitchenette). The location is fine if you are willing to take The Bus to get around; it's a 5 minute walk to the nearest "The Bus" stop; and it's about a 30 minute walk to Waikiki Beach, slightly less to Ala Moana Beach Park. There is a parking fee if you have a car. The kitchen is great to have if you have a family and want to save some money on meals. That said, there were some problems, although they were not serious. The worst was the nightly noise level from the street outside (we stayed in the building called the Pagoda Terrace; it's possible other buildings are quieter). The A/C drowned some of the noise but not enough for restful sleep. The kitchen was minimally equipped...two pots, dishes and flatware for 4, one sharp knife, one cutting board, one small two burner stove, coffeemaker (and coffee), fridge, microwave; but plenty of small "sugar ants" to get into any food left on the counter. The unit was older and somewhat worn, but otherwise clean. However the front desk person was very brusque upon check in., enough that I would try to stay elsewhere next time. MAKE SURE you have the EXACT SAME credit card you used to make the reservation and first night's deposit, as they will not allow you to use a different card to pay for the rest of your visit. This policy is to prevent ID theft, but the logic escaped me as we had ample photo ID to prove who we were and the reservations were made in our names! (We wound up paying with traveller's checks and having the original deposit credited back to our card). There was a nearby WiFi network we could access but it was not the hotel's network, and it was not always on. There are two small pools but the one at our building was full of small children whenever it was open. All in all the value for the money (about $140 with tax per night) was good, for a family, but next time I'd see if we could find something else.

Stayed at the Pagoda Hotel with a friend in early June. Conveniently located close to Waikiki (within 6 blocks), Ala Moana Shopping Center, Walmart and several "local" style restaurants. I like the location because its fairly centrally located, if Waikiki is not your only destinaton. Our room was in the Terrace across the street from the main lobby. The rooms were clean, but definitely shabby (cracked plaster, stained tub, chipped sink, "tired"/dated paint job). This place has definitely seen better days. It looks to be stuck in the late 60s/early 1970s era. The room had a coffeemaker, small refrigerator, microwave, sink and some kitchen utensils. Small bathroom and water temperature changes when someone on another floor flushes or uses the sinks. Small air conditioning unit, but it worked OK. Not great lighting, but better than some I've seen. Closet space was good and there is an in-room safe. Parking is included and there were adequate, but small spaces; additional parking is available in the Ross parking structure one block over. Maid service was inconsistent - one day our kitchen towels weren't touched and no new towels were put out; another day, everything was replenished incuding extra soaps, towels, etc. Staff were generally friendly; some of the other guests were more somber and standoff-ish.They have 2 pools, a gift shop, a beauty shop and travel/tour agency on site. The buffet restaurant across the street was nice and reasonable considering the offerings (with a Japanese/"local" slant). The restaurant has a massive fish pond filled with koi and nightly feedings are an event. Any phone messages to your room are taken by and then relayed to you by a live person, not a voicemail service. There was some noise from gardeners and other guests using the pool, but after 9pm it generally was quiet. Access to the terrace after hours is by keycard only.Pagoda seems to be a favorite for expatriates returning to Hawaii and low budget customers. It is generally cheaper than Waikiki hotels, but you do get what you pay for. I wouldn't stay here if you want any amenities or to impress anyone. But if you just want a bed and mostly clean room away from Waikiki, this would be OK.

I have stayed at the Pagoda Hotel in the past. It's a very good $ deal, BUT, this time I had extended family with me and we stayed in the Pagoda Terrace across the street. That was not so good. LOUD LOUD LOUD LOUD LOUD. Street noise on one side and googles of school kids going in and out and in and out of their rooms all night on the other side. Whew. I'm going to step it up the next time I go to Honolulu.

I have been taking college groups to the Pagoda for 15 years. My students love the Pagoda. It is a modest hotel , the staff is uniformly excellent, the location is superb and the restaurant is hard to beat anywhere in Honolulu. I would book the Pagoda again for my student groups in a heartbeat. Dr. William Stob

This hotel was absoutly dreadful . Bathrooms stunk to high heavens bugs everywhere, horrible service i was with my kids and they told them to F*** off.I told the manager and he told me the same thing.The food looked like it was going to be fed to pigs.Overall this place SUCKED do not stay here or you will be commiting a sin Thank you Moe Lester

Our room at the Pagoda was absolutely horrible and we definitely did not enjoy our stay! The room was filthy! The carpet and walls were extremely stained and beyond dirty! The bathroom was deplorable! The tiles on the floors were broken and the sink and tub were extremely dingy! The towels were smelly, thin and very old. There was a fist hole right in the middle of the bathroom door. One of the beds in the living room was right up next to the window air conditioner unit and it made for very uncomfortable resting. We even saw a roach scurry across the floor. The issues mentioned above are beyond any cleaners and/or vacuuming. Our room at the Pacific Monarch was beautiful, updated, and clean. We even had a partial ocean and city view. There are wonderful hotels in Hawaii for people on a budget. The Pagoda was not even decent!

stayed for 2 weeks in september 2005, to visit family. The room wa clean considering it could use some updating in furnishing. It is convieniently located to restaurants and shopping and most in walking distance. The room came with breakfast coupons for any entree at the hotel restaurant. The food was surprisingly very good and you can't beat the koi ponds and waterfall views from all angles. Very friendly staff who always greeted me. With the humidity and age of hotel, the staff keeps a spotless, fresh smelling place to stay, away from the busy waikiki area. Recommend if you are visiting friends and family and on a business trip.

The Good - the rooms were clean and were cleaned up very quickly each morning after we left to travel around the island. Loved getting the local paper delivered each morning (except for Sunday) at our door. Good breakfast at the restaurant. Didn't have a chance to try the lunch or dinner (where only the buffet was being served). Walking distance to the shopping center and about a mile from the start of Waikiki.The Bad - Kinda noisy. We were on the 4th floor side where deliveries were made at 5AM. Even being on the 4th floor, you could hear people talking below on the ground floor. The room air conditioner was right next to my bed so, it wasn't the greatest location.Fortunantly, our other 4th floor guests were very quiet, so no complaints or problems with noise. Overall - If you don't like to noise of city (garbage trucks backing up, car doors slamming, horns blowing, sirens in the distance) or a real light sleeper - don't stay here. Else - it's a good price so you can spend your money on other things (like Mai Tai's)

I just spent a week in one of the tower rooms, on the tenth floor, overlooking the pool and Rycroft St. I'd come back again. The hotel is a good budget hotel. The rooms are pretty much exactly as they look in pictures on the hotel website. The hotel in general is a little tattered around the edges, but the room was clean, everything worked, and the beds were pretty comfortable. The towels are quite thin, so you if you like thick and fluffy, bring your own.The pool is small. You can swim about 10 strokes and then you're at the other end. But it gets sun all day. While I was there, the hotel was pretty full, but the pool deck was never crowded. You can also walk to the beach at Ala Moana in about 15 minutes.The staff was friendly and efficient. The "floating restaurant" is pleasant. I only ate a light breakfast there a few times, which was fine. Nothing like having half a papaya every morning to remind you where you are! During the week, lunch is buffet only for $14.95. Dinner may also be buffet only during the week, I never tried.Biggest complaint: noise from the street. The garbage trucks arrive every morning about 5:15 and it's impossible to sleep through the noise while they empty the dumpsters. Late night also brings it share of noise from the parking lot of the 24-hr. restaurant down the block. Next time, I will ask for a room on the South side of the tower, hoping that it's a little quieter.The neighborhood is teeming with busy restaurants, predominantly Korean or Vietnamese. Also lots of Karaoke bars, strip clubs, and "relaxation" spas, probably because the Pagoda is only a few blocks from the Convention Center. You're also only a few blocks from the Ala Moana Shopping Center. If you're into shopping, you'll be in heaven. They have all the high-end designer stores, as well as shops in every price range. And the food court must have 20 different fast-food joints.

We recently stayed at the Pagoda Hotel in Honolulu (June 19-24, 2005). We were on a budget and I did a lot of research on the Internet with travel sites. I found a package deal on the hotel website (---) that included a deluxe room on an upper floor in the hotel tower (NOT the Terrace), breakfast from the menu at the hotel restaurant, a compact rental car and free parking – all for $133/night. The room was spacious and had a second sink and oversized vanity area in the bedroom. It had lots of mirrors and included a microwave and refrigerator. It was away from the traffic of Waikiki. The room was clean as was the entire hotel. The staff was friendly, but no extras - you tote your own bags. It was not a 5 star hotel, but probably a 3 star. It was within walking distance of the Ala Moana mall. The best feature was its proximity to a Walmart/Sam's Club - ONE BLOCK away! It was definitely a good deal, if you don’t need all the frills.

Aloha all! I'm a Kauai resident and I've stayed at the Pagoda numerous of times without a complaint in the world. They were always friendly and the rooms were always clean. I'd like to mention one thing that it seems most people mistakenly do. It is NOT known for LUXURY! If you decide to book a room here and want to be treated like a 3 star or 5 star hotel . . . you're looking at the wrong place. There are plenty of hotels in the Waikiki area more befitting this treatment. Keep in mind that you're going to pay more than $80 a night though. The Pagoda has been a 2nd home to my family and me. We've stayed in their studio and their terrace more than 3 times and we're quite satisfied. In fact, it's the only place to stay when going to Oahu and we have family up there! If you're looking for a clean place to stay for a couple of nights and a LOW COST, I'd recommend it. You get what you pay for. And who spends most of their vacation in the room any way? I like the fact that the front desk is available 24 hours, I like the fact there's a Ross's directly across the street, AND I like the fact that Likelike Drive In no more than a corner a way.

I had heard that the Pagoda Hotel was a popular choice among Hawaii residents visiting Oahu. In fact, I went there a few years ago when some friends from Hilo were staying there, and the room seemed "ok" at the time. So we booked a studio room in the Pagoda Terrace for our weekend trip to Oahu. We could have stayed with friends for free, but I thought it would be nicer to have our own hotel room than stay on someone's hide-a-bed. Wrong. I was SO disappointed. The room they gave us was smoky-smelling, old and dingy looking, and had two twin beds, not the best arrangement for a married couple. We were able to change rooms and get a double bed, but the room was equally dingy and smoky. I would have been willing to pay for an upgrade to a nicer, non-smoking room (I think the rooms in the tower are better) but none were available. Well, at least we had a kitchenette. Except that the microwave didn't work. And the hallways and elevators were dirty, with cigarette butts on the floor and stains on the carpet. We had to pay $5 a day for a parking pass, but then when we came back that night there was NO parking available in the structure. I circled the neighborhood for 10 minutes and finally found a metered spot where I parked for the night. When I called the front desk they said I also could have parked at the restaurant, but this is information that would have benefitted me more if given at the time of check-in. All these factors let my husband to affectionately nickname the hotel, "The Crapoda". I know it was a good deal, but I feel like we could have spend just a little more and stayed in a place that was actually halfway decent.

We stayed one night at the Pagoda Hotel and the remainder of our 7 nights at the Pagoda Suites. The first night was okay but the remainder of our stay was on the lower level beside the gate of the Pagoda Suites across from the main lobby. We had plenty of room for 5 people but the noise from people going in and out of the gate all night kept some of us awake. We also had some large roaches in the kitchen. They told us they have people coming to spray but not while we were there. The TV would not work properly but they eventually brought us another one after two tries to fix it. For the money, it was okay but if I had to do over again, I would stay the whole time across the street.

Staying at the Pagoda is like staying with relatives who aren't the best house keepers. The rooms are mostly clean, but not to mainland standards. The locals swear by this place, at least my wife does. Everyone I met there, both staff and guest were more open and down to earth than the other big hotels on the strip. I go to Hawaii to relax and enjoy life as the Hawaiians do. Having fun can sometimes be a little noisy. The Pagoda has a very good security force who are also very low key. I have always felt safe. Use common sense about your valuables. The food is fantastic, especially the dinner buffet. I will stay there again. Locals from the outer islands are the bread and butter for this property. Enjoy the chance to see real Hawaii. Aloha!

With my husband, my 2 young children and my mother in tow, we arrived in the hotel (terrace side) only to find a broken airconditioner and a ceiling fan desperately in need of an upgrade. To make things worse, you can not open any of the windows. The walls were bare, painted cream which made the room very dark- even with all the lights on. It did not look like any of the pictures that they advertised. The paint in the bedroom was peeling. The bathroom smelled and the bedsheets were soiled. The noise outside the hall was unbearable. We were scared to even go to sleep. We had no choice but stay that one night and were very lucky to find accommodations somewhere else. I would not recommend this hotel to anyone. Please give this hotel an extreme makeover.

My experience at the Pagoda hotel (tower side) was not a very good one. I would definentley avoid staying there again. The room was very dusty and there were people who lived there long term ( it seemed like) hanging outside our room and in the halls at all hours of the night and day. In the middle of the 2nd night I heard someone in the hall screaming and arguing with someone for about an hour straight! I felt very nervous for most of my time at the hotel.

I live in Honolulu, and stayed at the hotel recently when my condo was being remodeled. The rates are reasonable, and the rooms have been upgraded, to include a microwave and small refrigerator. It's a great hotel for people who don't want to be in the tourist ghetto of Waikiki; the restaurant (especially the buffet) and lounge are popular with locals. The staff is friendly, if not always efficient. I have friends from the mainland who won't stay any place BUT the Pagoda. They don't want to be in the tourist ghetto of Waikiki, and love the 24-hour Korean restaurant just across the street.

This will be my 3rd time staying at the pagoda. Yes if you stay at the hotel side it is much better then the other side across the street. People do live on the other side because it's cheaper than renting a house in Hawaii. The staff is friendly. If I felt it was not a good or safe placce to stay I would not be staying their again for a 3 time. It's a popular place with the locals. They have a great restaurant with great tasting food gotta try it even if you are not staying there.

A bunch of us were going to Oahu for a week trip, and we had gotten a good price for the kitchenette room. I had read the reviews and thought it couldnt be that bad, but i was wrong. The hotel smelled so disgusting. People lived there and were always in the hallways hanging around our room. the staff was very friendly. The rooms were clean but nothing special. Elevators are slow. While we were there all of our friends including us had got the flu not sure if it was from the hotel....and in our friends room they had found drug parafinalia in the closet. Finally we changed hotels, The Waikiki Terrace. This hotel was great. same price and it is right on the waikiki strip. I would not recomend the pagoda. I hope if you do stay there you will have a better experience.

I reserved a non-smoking room and got a smoking, which I couldn't change on check-in day. Was told that they would let us know if one was available later. The next day, around 2pm, I asked if there was a non-smoking; was told that I should have asked before noon. I was later shown a non-smoking room, which was worse than the smoking room we were in. The rooms, including the one we stayed in, were damp, moldy and stuffy. The room was probably vacuumed, but looked like it hadn't had any deep cleaning for decades; layers of dirt on the windows and air-conditioner; carpet pulling up and wrinkled; no vent in the bathroom, which made it even stuffier. The hotel looks like it hasn't been renovated since the 70's, which is not necessarily a bad thing, but coupled with the uncleanliness, and damp stuffiness, it is bad. Except for the room snafu, the staff was OK to indifferent. I would not stay there again. I've stayed in several Waikiki hotels and would take the bother of the traffic there before I go back to the Pagoda.

The wonderful staff really make the hotel. After only going there three times I feel like the staff is family. We keep in contact with them and look forward to each visit like going home. I have recommend this place to other.

The service was good. All of the employees were polite. The tower is a little nicer than the building across Rycroft street. There were lots of low income families staying long term in the building across the street. The hallways and elevator were also dirty. I would reccommend staying in Waikiki - nicer hotels at same cost, and closer to the beach, and more activities going on.

The Pagoda has two buildings; my experience was with the Terrace building (5-story building across the street from the tower). I had to drive around the block 4 times, then stop to ask for help before finding the entrance on Rycroft. The staff there were terrific; at my request, even sent me (COD) several items I'd left behind. The room was clean and large, with a full kitchen. The value was terrific. The elevator and hallways were dirty. There were lots of people hanging around, apparantly long-term foreign (?) residents staying in Honolulu for medical treatment. The restaurant was delightful in its setting above an extensive koi pond. A car was essential to get around and to the beaches, since the Pagoda is off the beaten path. But it is very close to the Ala Moano Shopping Center and convenient to Ward Center. A stay at the Pagoda is a great place to get a more Hawaiian experience (rather than staying on Waikiki with all the other mainlanders).
